discussion.content: I think B and E are correct answers here.

questions.question_text: End-to-end encryption is a management requirement for a wireless deployment. When importing the WLCs into Cisco Prime infrastructure 2.0, which two options represent the version of SNMP and remote access parameter that fulfill this requirement? (Choose two.)

choices.C: guest-mode on the dot11 radio interface
choices.B: dot11 mbssid globally and mbssid mode under the SSIDs
choices.A: the new SSID on the 5-GHz radio

questions.question_text: The network administrator wants an access point to be able to find rogue APs and to support location-based services. Which AP mode meets this requirement while having the radios up and preventing client connections?

discussion.content:
A is not correct because in "Rogue Detector" mode, the radio is disabled and no location based services are supported.
B is not correct because in "sniffer" mode, the AP forwards data to an external application (so cannot detect rogue devices), and does not support location based service.
C is not correct because in "Flexconnect" mode, the AP is only serving clients and cannot detect rogue devices.
D is correct because in "monitor mode", the radio is enabled for listening only and does not serve clients. It offers rogue detection and location based services.

questions.answer_description:
If you have enough access points, you can even dedicate an AP to making it's only job picking up other networks, this a mode that the AP can be in and is called
"Monitor Mode" to change an AP to monitor mode, navigate to the following on the WLC:
This will place the AP into a dedicated monitor mode, it will not service clients but will sit and scan for you.

questions.question_text: Which type of authentication is used initially by a controller-based AP so that a guest client can get an IP address?
questions.answer_description: Open authentication allows any device to authenticate and then attempt to communicate with the access point. Using open authentication, any wireless device can authenticate with the access point, but the device can communicate only if its Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) keys match the access point's WEP keys. Devices that are not using WEP do not attempt to authenticate with an access point that is using WEP. Open authentication does not rely on a RADIUS server on your network. http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/access/wireless/software/guide/ SecurityAuthenticationTypes.html#wp1035025

discussion.content: Following the rules of 3db and 10db: 3db doubles the power output and 10db increases it by tenfold. Adding 10db brings the power level to 30mw, then adding another 3db doubles it to bring the power level to 60mw.

questions.question_text: A network engineer notices that two mesh APs are having problems communicating. After reviewing the current radio configurations, it is noted that one AP is transmitting at 3 mW while the other is transmitting at 60 mW. How many decibels would the 3-mW AP need its power increased to match the 60-mW AP?
